column2: In graph theory, an adjacent vertex of a vertex \(v\) in a graph is a vertex that is connected to \(v\) by an edge.
In formal language theory, an alphabet \(\Sigma\) is a non-empty set of symbols.
Let T\(:=(T,(B_{t})_{t \in V(T)})\) be a tree-decomposition. The sets \(B_{t}\) are called bags.

If \(f,g\) are two functions from \(\mathbb{N}\) to \(\mathbb{N}\), then: \begin{enumerate} \item \(f =O(g)\) exists if there exists a constant \(c\) such that \(f(n) \leq c \cdot g(n)\) for every sufficiently large \(n\),\item \(g=O(f) \implies f=\Omega (g)\)\item \(f=\Theta(g) \iff{} (f = O(g) \land g= O(f))\)\item \(f = o(g)\) if for every \(\epsilon > 0, f(n) \leq \epsilon \cdot g(n)\) for every sufficiently large \(n\),\item \(g=o(f) \implies f=\omega(g)\) \(g=o(f)\) \end{enumerate} To Emphasize the input parameter, another notation is \(f(n)=O(g(n))\) instead of \(f=O(g)\). Similar notations can be used for \(o,\Omega,\omega,\Theta.\)

In graph theory, a bramble for an undirected graph \(G\) is a family of connected subgraphs of \(G\) where for every pair of disjoint subgraphs, there must exist an edge in \(G\) that has one endpoint in each subgraph.

A language \(L \subseteq \{0,1\}^{\ast}\) is in NP if there exists a polynomial \(p: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) and a polynomial time Turing Machine \(M\) such that for every \(x \in \{0,1\}^{\ast},\) \[x \in L \Leftrightarrow \exists u \in \{0,1\}^{p(|x|)} \text{ so that } M(x,u)=1.\] If \(x \in L\) and \(u \in \{0,1\}^{p(|x|)}\) satisfy \(M(x,u)=1\) then we call \(u\) a certificate for \(x\) with respect to \(L\) and \(M\).
The number \[\chi(G):=\min\{k:G \text{ is } k \text{-colourable}\}\] is called the chromatic number of \(G\).
In set theory and its applications throughout mathematics, a class is a collection of sets or other mathematical objects that can be unambiguously defined by a property that all its members share.
The clique number \(\omega(G)\) of a graph \(G\) is the number of vertices in a maximum clique in \(G\).
In graph theory, the clique problem is the computational problem of finding cliques/complete subgraphs in a graph.
A clique or complete subgraph \(C\), in an undirected graph \(G = (V, E)\) is a subset of the vertices, \(C \subseteq V\), such that every two distinct vertices are adjacent.

A closed walk consists of a sequence of vertices starting and ending at the same vertex, with each two consecutive vertices in the sequence adjacent to each other in the graph. In a directed graph, each edge must be traversed by the walk so that the edge must be oriented from the earlier of two consecutive vertices to the later of the two vertices in the sequence.
In graph theory, a complete graph is a simple undirected graph in which every pair of distinct vertices is connected by a unique edge.
A graph \(G\) is connected if any two of its vertices are connected by a path.
A maximally connected subgraph of \(G\) is called a component of \(G\).

A condition \(P(x)\) holds for sufficiently large \(x \in \mathbb{R}\) if there exists some \(X \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \(P(x)\) holds for every \(x > X\). \[\exists x \in \mathbb{R}: \forall x \in \mathbb{R}: x \geq X \implies P(x)\]
In graph theory, a cycle is a path of edges and vertices wherein a vertex is reachable from itself.
In graph theory, the degree/valency of a vertex of a graph is the number of edges incident to the vertex, with loops counted twice.

column1: Density of an Undirected Simple Graph
column2: For undirected simple graph density is defined as: \[D=\dfrac{2|E|}{|V|(|V|-1)}\]
In mathematics and computer science, a directed acyclic graph, is a finite directed graph with no directed cycles.
For directed simple graph density is defined as: \[D=\dfrac{|E|}{|V|(|V|-1)}\]
In graph theory, a dominating set for a graph \(G = (V, E)\) is a subset \(D\) of \(V\) such that every vertex not in \(D\) is adjacent to at least one member of \(D\).
The dominating set problem concerns testing whether \(\gamma(G) \leq K\) for a given graph \(G\) and input \(K\).
The domination number \(\gamma(G)\) is the number of vertices in a smallest dominating set for \(G\).
An edge contraction is an operation which removes an edge from a graph while simultaneously merging the two vertices it used to connect.
In set theory and its applications throughout mathematics, a class is a collection of sets or other mathematical objects that can be unambiguously defined by a property that all its members share.
A finite graph is a graph in which the vertex set and the edge set are finite sets.
A formal language \(L\) over an alphabet \(\Sigma\) is a set of words over that alphabet.
A graph is an ordered pair \(G = (V, E)\) comprising a set \(V\) of vertices/nodes/points together with a set \(E\) of edges.
In mathematics, a hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices.
In graph theory, an independent set or stable set is a set of vertices in a graph, no two of which are adjacent.
Let \(k \geq 0\). A graph \(G\) is \(k\)-colourable if there is a mapping \(c:V(G) \rightarrow \{1, \ldots, k\}\) such that if \(\{u,v\} \in E(G), \text{ then } c(u) \neq c(v).\)
In graph theory, a loop is an edge that connects a vertex to itself.
A maximal clique is a clique that cannot be extended by including one more adjacent vertex, that is, a clique which does not exist exclusively within the vertex set of a larger clique.
A maximum clique of a graph \(G\), is a clique, such that there is no clique with more vertices.
A maximum independent set is an independent set of largest possible size for a given graph \(G\).
A minimum vertex cover is a vertex cover of smallest possible size.

An undirected graph \(H\) is a minor of another undirected graph \(G\) if a graph isomorphic to \(H\) can be obtained from \(G\) by contracting some edges, deleting some edges, and deleting some isolated vertices.
A multigraph is a graph which is permitted to have edges that have the same end nodes. Thus two vertices may be connected by more than one edge.
In graph theory, multiple edges/parallel edges/ multi-edge, are two or more edges that are incident to the same two vertices.

A language \(L \subseteq \{0,1\}^{\ast}\) is in NP if there exists a polynomial \(p: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) and a polynomial time Turing Machine \(M\) such that for every \(x \in \{0,1\}^{\ast},\) \[x \in L \Leftrightarrow \exists u \in \{0,1\}^{p(|x|)} \text{ so that } M(x,u)=1.\]

A one-tape turing machine is defined as a \(7\)-tuple \(M = \langle Q, \Gamma, b, \Sigma, \delta, q_0, F \rangle\) where: \begin{description} \item[\(Q\)] is a finite, non-empty set of states \item[\(\Gamma\)] is a non-empty set of symbols \item[\(b \in \Gamma\)] is a blank symbol \item[\(\Sigma \subseteq \Gamma \setminus \{b\}\)] is the set of input symbols \item[\(\delta :(Q\setminus F) \times \Gamma \rightarrow Q \times \Gamma \times \{L,R\}\)] is a partial function called the transition function \item[\(q_0 \in Q\)] is the initial state\end{description}
The order of a bramble is the smallest size of a hitting set, a set of vertices of \(G\) that has a nonempty intersection with each of the subgraphs.

An oracle Turing machine \(M\) is a \(TM\) that has a special read-write tape oracle tape and three special states \(q_{query},q_{yes},q_{no}\). In addition to the input there is a language \( O \subseteq \{0,1\}^{\ast}\) used as the oracle for \(M\). Whenever during the  execution \(M\) enters the state \(q_{query}\) the machine moves into the state \(q_{yes}\) if \(q \in O\) and \(q_{no}\) if \( q \not \in O\), where \(q\) denotes the contents of the special oracle tape. Regardless of the choice of \(O\), a membership query to \(O\) counts as a single computational step.
A path is a trail in which all vertices except possibly the first and last are distinct.
In graph theory, a regular graph is a graph where every vertex has the same degree or valency.
Let T\(:=(T,(B_{t})_{t \in V(T)})\) be a tree-decomposition. For an edge \(\{s,t\} \in E(T)\), we call \(B_{s} \cap B_{t}\) the seperator at \(\{s,t\}\).
A set is independent if and only if its complement is a vertex cover.

A simple graph, as opposed to a multigraph, is an undirected graph in which both parallel edges/multiple edges and loops are disallowed. In a simple graph the edges form a set rather than a multiset and each edge is an unordered pair of distinct vertices.
A tree-decomposition \((T,(B_{t})_{t \in V(T)})\) is called small, if \(B_{t} \not \subseteq B_{u}\) for all \(t \neq u \in V(T).\)
In formal language theory, a string or word is defined as a finite sequence of symbols .
In formal language theory, the elements of an alphabet are called symbols or letters.
A trail is a walk in which all edges are distinct.

A tree-decomposition of a graph \(G\) is a pair T \(:=(T, B_{t})_{t \in V(T)})\) consisting of a tree \(T\) and a family \((B_t)_{t \in V(T)}\) of sets \(B_{t} \subseteq V(G)\), such that: \begin{enumerate} \item for all \(v \in V(G)\) the set \[B^{-1}(v):=\{t \in V(T):v \in B_{t}\}\]is non-empty and incudes a subtree of \(T\) \item for every edge \(e \in E(G)\) there is \(t \in V(T)\) with \(e \subseteq B_{t}\).\end{enumerate}
The tree-width \(tw(G)\) of \(G\) is defined as the minimal width of any tree-decomposition of \(G\).

Let \(f: \{0,1\}^ \ast \rightarrow \{0,1\}^\ast\) and let \(T: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) be some functions, and let \(M\) be a Turing Machine. We say that \(M\) computes \(f\) if for every \(x \in \{0,1\}^\ast\), whenever \(M\) is initialized to the start configuration on input \(x\), then it halts with \(f(x)\) written on its output tape.

A language \(L \subseteq \{0,1\}^{\ast}\) is in NP if there exists a polynomial \(p: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) and a polynomial time Turing Machine \(M\) called verifier for \(L\) such that for every \(x \in \{0,1\}^{\ast},\) \[x \in L \Leftrightarrow \exists u \in \{0,1\}^{p(|x|)} \text{ so that } M(x,u)=1.\]

A vertex cover \(V'\) of an undirected graph \(G = ( V , E )\) is a subset of \(V\) such that \(u v \in E \Rightarrow u \in V' \lor v \in V'\), that is to say it is a set of vertices \(V'\) where every edge has at least one endpoint in the vertex cover \(V’\). Such a set is said to cover the edges of \(G\).
The vertex cover number \(\tau\) is the size of a minimum vertex cover: \[\tau = |V'|\].

A walk of length \(k\) in a graph is an alternating sequence of vertices and edges, \(v_{0},e_{0},v_{1},e_{1},v_{2},\ldots ,v_{k-1},e_{k-1},v_{k}\), which begins and ends with vertices. If the graph is undirected, then the endpoints of \(e_{i}\) are \(v_{i}\) and \(v_{i+1}\). If the graph is directed, then \(e_{i}\) is an arc from \(v_{i}\) to \(v_{i+1}\).
The width \(w(\text{T})\) of T is \(w(\text{T}):=\max\{|B_{t}|-1: t \in V(T)\}.\)
